comments.commentBody: stu, I get it.

Obama and reid are leftists? That is the biggest laugh I have had in quite some while. They barely qualify as centrists. And with 80 tea party members of the house, there are certainly far right extremists in the house and the senate has a number of them too.
The number of liberals in either house can be counted on one hand.

Skip: you choose to view politics from the left extreme only - to a radical liberal most people are rightists or extreme right. It's just a distorted perspective, like, for example, saying six foot eight man is short, or four foot nine man is tall.
Obama and Reid are definitely leftists using our entire population as reference.
Newsflash: Triumph for Ole Miss as the hack beats the lunatic!

There is a big mis-perception that people younger than boomers don't have any investable assets. Just saw very reliable data that disproves that point.

As for the "evil" aspect of investing - again, not so at all. Investors today can find some very well managed portfolios and funds that are carefully screened to reduce and/or eliminate objectionable companies and industries that don't fit their preferences.

Your statement about Kurdistan is all speculation. The Kurds already had some sort of autonomy even under Saddam.

On the justification for removing Saddam by force, you are playing into people's emotions by playing this "evil vs good" scheme. I think most of the world would have agreed that forcefully removing the Bush administration and its officials would also have been an unadulterated good (?).

If there is a bad captain on a ship, you don't sink the entire ship and claim that you were only targeting the bad captain.

No one in the world elected American governments to be the "moral police" of the world. In fact, most of the world opposes if not abhors this hegemonic supremacist American behavior. Americans want to believe that they are unlike any other nation on the history of the planet and that they are not the other colonial hegemonic. Well, we really appreciate this ideal but the facts on the ground point to the opposite. This is like the Muslim fundamentalist delusional view that theology has the solution to all issues, ranging from political to economical.
I knew it!  Bush was right and Obama is wrong!  Brilliant!

..really??? Do people believe neo-con invasion of Iraq was about "morality"???
"Operation Iraqi Liberation"=O.I.L.

"Tunisia and Kurdistan...are works in progress, but what is important is that they did emerge from the societies themselves."

It is a shame that Mr. Friedman did not recognize this BEFORE he supported the US invasion of Iraq: that meaningful changes in countries in the Middle East must come from within, and NOT be arrogantly forced on them by an insane US invasion. 4500 US lives could have been saved, as well as countless innocent Iraqis.

We have turned the clock back in Iraq by at least a generation by our ignorant and arrogant assumption, the we, the US, know better what leader Iraq needs. We have destroyed the Iraqi infrastructure, economy, and administrative infrastructure, as non-democratic as that may have been. And we have certainly set back the fate of women in Iraq by at least a generation by setting the stage of a fundamentalist takeover. Women in Saddam's Iraq were an integral part of society; now they are being forced back into the shadows.

And please, Mr. Friedman, what new insights have you provided us here? Nothing! The situation you describe in the Arab world in your usual breathless - "oh, I've come up with this brilliant conclusion" - is identical to what it has been for generations, just replace Sisi with any of the previous Egyptian dictators, and ISIS with last year's model of Islamic fundamentalism, many born and nurtured by our "good buddies", the Saudis.

And then, of course there is the obligatory Friedman "cutesy", ISIS and SISI - oh, how clever!

Perhaps sam pan the puzzle, but most will praise it, methinks.

:) right back to you.
This was a simple-but-solid Wednesday crossword. Amusing puns, original clues... And though the fill was junk-less, I still managed to sail through it pretty well. :)

Yeah, I guess you support incumbents like Cochran who does not care about your income only care about his LIFE TIME benefits which would out last you and his promoted salary ( he voted for automically salary up to 200,000 a year.. He agreed to let President Obama to have his up grade to have 1 million salary!! I don't care how honorable all incumbents are..., even at their ages like 74 years old of Thad's..
Only less than 15 percent of African American and 75% of White in the state of Mississippi.. Why would Thad Cochran need the African American votes in that state.. only less than the majority votes of Whites!! I bet Thad will lose in November! Why we need 75 years old and who understand the needs the young generation have.. I

In my earlier comment, I lamented the fact that there are men whose political professionalism is seemingly or obviously questionable. Believing Mr. Brat created an opportunity for the Tea Party, Mr. McDaniel, as expected, tried, but to no avail, rode on the former's coat tail. The latter failed to realize that decent people in Mississippi are not as stupid as Mr. McDaniel might have thought.

I salute Senator Cochran for running a spirited campaign. This is where true statesmanship begins. Having been senator over several terms, his wisdom and savvy in handling the business of the people prove that seasoned leadership is at its best.

More power to you and the office thy represent, Senator Thad Cochran.

And for the also-run other than the loser? Quo vadis...Mr. McDaniel?
They wouldn't elect a Democrat in Mississippi if Jesus was on the ballot.

Yeah that Cochran!!
He's defied his party on so many occasions you don't even need a finger to add em all up!!
Better to have a traditional time-serving pol, than an extremist.

rimantas asks "However, don't the liberal voters for Cochran have a problem to explain why they voted for antiObama, antiReid candidate?"

Answer: he is less extreme than the other guy, who is totally off the wall.

They are not voting "for" Cochran.

They are voting "against" McDaniel. It is the one forum where they can actually say "no" to him, and have it matter.
This primary system has been in effect in a few other states for a long time.  CA gets the attention because of its size and influence, of course.  I recommend it to every state.

Funny, Mac K, but when Patrick M was Jim Horne's co-pilot, my pronounced propensity for punning was greatly frowned upon!
However, If I may take the "Liberty" of saying, the only flaw in the FLUE this night, by our beloved constructor that I took a rather Dim View of, was UPLIT @2D!

The answer @ 56A RUTHLESSTACTICS was a clear-cut Classic!
TIRELESSWORKERS @20A didn't exactly Rubber this HAM the wrong way, either!
In closing, although it wasn't exactly a STOKE of genius, there was nary a need for this solver to KNOX it, thus no SABERs were crossed!
OBSCENE a lot worse in my time!
Provided, of course, I didn't MYTH my guess?

Howie
PS, For my Doe, I can't say I wasn't terribly Fawn of the clue for 12D?

Thanks for saying that! There are certainly a lot of problems in Mississippi, but so many commentators in these pages are guilty of assuming that everyone is Mississippi who is white must be stupid and racist. Watch Anthony Bourdain's Parts Unknown about the Delta; he makes a good point, as you have, that privileged liberals in the North don't live with this difficult past day to day like people of different races do here. There are some who want to turn back the clock; there are many who are understandably still angry; and there are many who want to work together to make progress. And poverty complicates everything.

If they police their own party, then why did Cochran need Democrats to win?

This was racism by whites who work in Memphis but live in Mississippi plain and simple. Cochran is on shaky ground and I bet he retires soon.

Except most believe politicians out scoundrels.  They sometimes are rich themselves and have heirs.  I'm not sure most agree that they trust politicians to do the right thing.  Most elections are voting the lesser of two evils.

So, don't elect scoundrels.  Reform the political process so that voters can elect true representatives.  If the problem is with the political process, don't rely on the plutocracy to remedy that.  They will never do that.  That is not how democracy is supposed to work.

Mankiew's defense of inherited wealth is welcome in the sense that it lays bare the stark choices that we face.  Should we hand over our collective resources to a plutocracy hoping for a  benign, paternalistic trickle down that benefits us after the appetite of the plutocrats is met; or should we leave most of these resources in the hands of the people's representatives that we can hold accountable for addressing the well being of the overwhelming majority of us?  If you believe in democracy the choice seems obvious.

Inherited dynastic wealth was earned by dead people. Dead people are not legal persons, not even under the 14th amendment.

Regarding the dead hand of the past and the conservative American tradition, you know it's against the rule, there could be after born and 22.

The rule against perpetuities expresses with the force of centuries of law (recently repealed by oligarchs) the non novel command, keep the dead hand of the past off this and future generations.

The wealth that matters is the wealth that commands access to the commonwealth. The rest is delusional. Maroon a billionaire with her billions and her dynastic family if you doubt it.

Too bad real conservatives are extinct and have been replaced by sulk waaaaah conservatives who are to real conservatives as Comanche to Cherokee.

Have you seen The Hunger Games? Think of the Waltons, the Kochs, the Adelsons, the Romneys all decked out in regalia watching the rest of us fight it out for a few scraps and maybe a life. Pretty cool, maybe we could make it happen in real life?

An economic assumption and perhaps a couple constitutional issues seem to be ignored here. Granted, the governmental seizure of accumulated wealth via a wealth tax and redistribution through all means of social channels would perhaps get that wealth back in the hands of the populace more quickly-but why is that the goal. This assumes that wealth is finite and that the accumulation of it by families necessarily deprives others. Not to mention , how about the simple fact that those who earned it get to keep it--a sadly novel concept apparently

Thad Cochran should just go to sleep during the general campaign, let his democratic opponent win and let his state come into the 21st century. In his heart of heart he knows this is the best thing he can do for Mississippi.

Mark, Lebanon had a civil war for 15 years. Israel was in Lebanon for only 10 in an attempt to protect her own citizens.

Mark, I lived in Michigan for seven months. I've also been in Israel for weeks at a time on multiple occasions. I love both places. But trust me, the Middle East is not the Midwest.

The Lebanese Civil War kicked off with the massacre on 13 April 1975 of 30 Palestinians by the paramilitary that Israeli intelligence had been developing.
http://publishing.cdlib.org/ucpressebooks/view?docId=kt2k401947&chun...

The outright Israeli invasion aimed at those same Palestinians came 15 March 1978. Its purpose was to destroy those same Palestinians that were targeted in the massacre by the Israeli-supported paramilitary less than three years before. The Israelis did not withdraw from the Security Belt they occupied with the help of their paramilitary until 24 May 2000.

Lebanon's catastrophe dates from the Israeli sponsorship of those paramilitaries, for the purpose of targeting Palestinians in Lebanon. Until that outside push, Lebanon's unique confessional system of democracy was working, despite tensions as population shifted from the percentages between groups built into the system.

somebody always has to mention the Palestinians and Israel in any article on the Middle East. that was a favored tactic of the Arab 'leaders'. distract the masses from their own country's internal problems by focusing their hatred on the infidel Jews. how come you never similarly digress to countries like Egypt, Sudan, the Central African Republic, Syria, Pakistan etc. when an article directly concerns Israel and the Palestinians? it's ok, readers who pay attention know the answer.
Lebanon was hardly a stable country when Israel 'invaded'. the country was a launching pad for the PLO- basically Syria, Egypt and Jordan were too smart to allow such groups to operate from their territories, fearful of Israeli reprisals. the country was simply the first to suffer implosion due to Shias and Sunnis warring with each other. toss in the Christian faction, much larger and powerful than in Syria and Iraq, the country was a quagmire. would you deny the USA the right to 'invade' Canada or Mexico if we were repeatedly the victims of aggression from across the border?

Odd that your Israeli guide doesn't see the Palestinians under Abbas, who are not SISI or ISIS. He doesn't see Lebanon either, which was a modern democracy that functioned well until the Israeli invasion and occupation.

Instead he sees that we must wait another generation before anything can change from the status quo. Odd who seems to cling to the status quo -- it isn't any of the Arabs, of any opinion.
After the nursing home fiasco and the courthouse caper, you see the Tea Party as adults?  Interesting....

Repressing the black population of Miss. was their strategy all along, to make them work for less and longer hours with no breaks. That's a recipe for high turn-over and low, low, wages. And replace them with Guatemalans who'll labor for even less with even fewer benefits.

It's straight out of the plantation.

I hear people say that but it is not true. As bad as the US is, I have lived in countries much worse.

And I have lived in countries better. Go visit Sweden and Germany and Netherlands. People are better educated, more cooperative, and have better mobility.

Sad when one realizes we are the wealthiest country on the planet.

Interesting comments.  I wonder how many of these Tea Party "patriots" actually voted for the man (George W. Bush) whose policies, both domestic and foreign, actually put us in the situation you've just described?  How many of these Tea Party patriots actually bought the bunk of "weapons of mass destruction in Iraq" and cheered on this country's invasion?  My guess is that a lot of them did, now they're crying because it's time to pay the piper.  Same thing goes for the government "overreach" you speak of.  Your "high taxes" will come soon - just be patient - and they will come as a result of the wars and policies the Bush Administration started and enacted.
From what I've read about MS and where they fit in with the rest of the states it doesn't seem any of their politicians have "done a good job for his state".  They really should be very embarrassed.

Martin, Dr. RUTH Westheimer?

Howie wonder where she art?

If this is the *best* the TEA Party can do after spending $10 million or so in one of the most conservative (reactionary) states is the country, I don't think they should be feeling too chipper about their prospects. People are catching on. Cochran got a small number of black votes out of the 190,000 or so total. The rest were "normal" Republicans, presumably conservative.

Another "big win" for resigned Governor of Alaska "Sara WHO??"

I share your skepticism of his gratitude.  To be realistic, though, what Thad Cochran has done to reward Democrats who voted for him is to keep Chris McDaniel out of the U.S. Senate.  Anything else he does for them is just gravy.
